I've been thinking about having the ability to create and manage groups of virtualenvs. A natural use for this would be to create a virtualenv for each interpreter available. Then you could do something like "virtualenvgroup myproj cmd" and cmd would be applied to each virtualenv in the group. (pip install, nosetest, etc..)
I typically activate a venv, start a screen (byobu) session, and then set a friendly name for the session so I can easily jump back and forth using "screen -r proj1|proj2..."
Of course, you can always start multiple envs within the same screen session as well

This might be a documentation enhancement rather than a feature, but I'd love to know how to install it system-wide and/or add the "source /usr/local/bin/virtualenvwrapper.sh" or similar line to every new user's .bashrc file automatically.
"Every new user" => add it to /etc/skel/.bashrc (at least on Ubuntu, may differ for other distributions)
(N.B. above paths are likely to be the same on Debian as I doubt the Ubuntu maintainers would have changed them)
"system-wide" => /etc/bash.bashrc (again Ubuntu specific) though savvy users defining their own .bashrc may not be sourcing this file and would thus lose your additions
